doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Global Markets Daily Oil Prices And Traded Inflation Demand vs Supply SchaperGlobal Markets Daily Oil Prices And Traded _2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: Oil prices and traded inflation displa strong correlation, despite the only modest share of energy prices in overall inflation baskets. We find that oil price shocks significantly boost traded inflation and flatten the breakeven curve across USD, EUR and GBP traded inflation markets. European markets are more exposed to oil shocks than the US, due to their larger import share of oil.

We distinguish between oil supply and demand shocks, and find that demand shocks have a stronger effect on traded inflation than supply shocks, with front- end breakevens 15- 25bp higher two weeks after the initial shock, about twice as large as for supply shocks. Longer tenors are less exposed.

Front- end real rates tend to fall in response to positive demand shocks, against expectations, as nominal rates do not reprice higher quickly enough to offset the inflationary effect. Instead, positive supply shocks only modestly compress front- end rates, but push long- end real rates higher.

Falling oil prices on the back of a supply glut, as our strategists expect, should continue to drag European traded inflation lower. And while for now we maintain our view of no incremental Russian energy exports, an eventual peace deal and potentially increased supply would be a further drag on breakevens, and a headwind to the repricing higher to factor in the improved growth outlook.

Although energy prices comprise only a modest portion of overall inflation baskets, oil prices explain a significant share of the variation in traded inflation markets. This holds not only at the front- end of the inflation curve, but is also true for longer- dated forwards (Exhibit 1). One potential explanation for the strong correlation between medium- term traded inflation and oil prices could be the salience of petrol prices in consumers' minds and thus in setting inflation expectations. Those, in turn, are an important input factor for medium- term inflation in most economic models. We find that petrol prices have a much stronger explanatory power for setting consumers' inflation expectations than other inflation components (Exhibit 2). On the other hand, energy price spikes feed into inflation quickly, albeit typically not for long, as supply rebalancing or the monetary response bring prices down again.

Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. For Reg AC certification and other important disclosures, see the Disclosure Appendix, or go to www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
Exhibit 1: Oil prices almost perfectly correlate with medium-term traded inflationWTI, 1st contract vs US CPI 5y5y Swap
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,Goldman Sachs FICC and Equities
Exhibit 2: Energy prices are a dominant factor in setting consumers inflation expectations
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,Haver Analytics

To analyse the link between traded inflation and oil prices in more detail, we first use a VAR model that includes controls for the exchange rate. We find that a \(10\%\) positive oil price shock leads to a significant increase in traded inflation across the curve in USD, EUR and GBP traded inflation markets. As expected, oil price shocks more strongly affect shorter tenors, which rise by 15- 25bp after two weeks across markets (Exhibit 3). The belly and long end of the inflation curve rise more modestly, with 10y breakeven up by about 5- 10bp after two weeks. In line with the literature, we find a stronger response in EUR and GBP than in USD, which is consistent with the former two economies' greater exposure to commodity prices in their inflation baskets. This potentially also reflects the greater vulnerabilities to commodities shocks (or at least the perception of such) of smaller, open economies that rely exclusively on imports.

Although there is a clear link between oil and traded inflation, we find a much less systematic relationship between oil prices and real rates. Our analysis suggests that real rates decline slightly in response to oil price changes, but the effect is modest and only significant for short tenors. Instead, we think this is evidence that the ultimate real (and thus nominal) rate response should depend on the driver of oil price movements - namely, whether the oil price movements are driven by demand or supply factors.
Two- week cumulative impulse response of zero- coupon inflation swaps to \(10\%\) oil price shock
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Goldman Sachs FICC and Equities
Predicted vs actual change in inflation curve during Israel- Iran war, June 2025
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Goldman Sachs FICC and Equities

To distinguish between supply and demand shocks, we develop a model based on prior Fed research, that decomposes changes in oil prices into these two factors. We can then use these decomposed demand and supply oil price shocks to sharpen our estimates of inflation sensitivity. Consistent with theory and the literature, across the different markets we find that demand shocks boost traded inflation more strongly than supply shocks. Demand shocks have the strongest effect on the front end and belly of the inflation curve, with 2y breakeven up 10- 20bp after two weeks across markets (Exhibit 5). Further out the curve, the effect roughly halves, as markets presumably maintain confidence that central banks will eventually prevent the economy from overheating and thereby contain the inflationary effect in the medium term. The corollary of this is that markets should also reprice real rates higher in expectation of this reaction. However, while there is no systematic effect on longer- dated rates, we find that short- term real rates decline initially, as nominal rates do not rise sufficiently or quickly enough to buffer the inflationary impulse (Exhibit 7).
Impulse Response using local projections of \(10\%\) demand oil price shock, Inflation Swaps
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Goldman Sachs FICC and Equities
Impulse Response using local projections of \(10\%\) supply oil price shock, Inflation Swaps
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Goldman Sachs FICC and Equities

Supply- driven \(10\%\) oil price shocks, on the other hand, tend to raise short- dated breakevens by around 5bp, while longer tenors are mainly flat (Exhibit 6). For the real economy, supply shocks, or "cost- push shocks," simultaneously increase inflation and hamper growth, as production factors become scarcer. That complicates the monetary response, as the different mandates of maximising employment and ensuring price stability come into direct conflict. Consistent with this, we find a more negative effect on front- end real rates in the US (as the Fed has been explicitly given a dual mandate and thus needs to weigh the monetary response more carefully) than in the Euro area (where the ECB pursues a single mandate of price stability). Longer- dated real rates in the Euro area do see a modest increase (Exhibit 8). Further, we find no significant increase in longer- dated breakevens, as markets price in the expectation of a slowdown in growth and inflation undershoot in the future, in line with the theoretical prediction.

Such spikes in traded inflation, however, are usually short- lived, with the effect typically fading after a few weeks. Further, we have shown in our fair value model that energy prices are a dominant factor in driving traded inflation, but that this relationship is not linear, with oil prices below €75/bbl adding a significant drag to traded inflation.
Impulse Response using local projections of \(10\%\) demand oil price shock, Real Rates
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Goldman Sachs FICC and Equities
Impulse Response using local projections of \(10\%\) supply oil price shock, Real Rates
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Goldman Sachs FICC and Equities

We can use these estimates as a simple rule of thumb, which for example worked well during the recent brief conflict between Israel and Iran, which led to a temporary spike in oil prices due to supply concerns (Exhibit 4). While non- OPEC and OPEC supply increases continue to bias oil prices lower in the near term (our oil strategists expect Brent to average \(64 / bbl\) in 2025Q4 and \(56 in 2026\) ), geopolitical risk in the Middle East persists, which could cause a future oil price spike. On the other hand, a potential Ukraine peace deal could lead to increased oil and gas flows from Russia - or at least shift the distribution of risks. For now, our strategists do not expect a significant impact, given that a restoration of pipeline flows remains unlikely in the near term, but eventual increased supply, and lower energy prices in general, could act as a further drag on European traded inflation in particular.

implemented into United Kingdom domestic law and regulation following the United Kingdom's departure from the European Union and the European Economic Area) with regard to regulatory technical standards for the technical arrangements for objective presentation of investment recommendations or other information recommending or suggesting an investment strategy and for disclosure of particular interests or indications of conflicts of interest is available at https://www.gs.com/disclosures/europeanpolicy.html which states the European Policy for Managing Conflicts of Interest in Connection with Investment Research.

Japan: Goldman Sachs Japan Co., Ltd. is a Financial Instrument Dealer registered with the Kanto Financial Bureau under registration number Kinsho 69, and a member of Japan Securities Dealers Association, Financial Futures Association of Japan Type II Financial Instruments Firms Association, The Investment Trusts Association, Japan, and Japan Investment Advisers Association. Sales and purchase of equities are subject to commission pre- determined with clients plus consumption tax. See company- specific disclosures as to any applicable disclosures required by Japanese stock exchanges, the Japanese Securities Dealers Association or the Japanese Securities Finance Company.

Goldman Sachs International ("GSI"), authorised by the Prudential Regulation Authority ("PRA") and regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority ("FCA") and the PRA, has approved this research in connection with its distribution in the United Kingdom.

European Economic Area: GSI, authorised by the PRA and regulated by the FCA and the PRA, disseminates research in the following jurisdictions within the European Economic Area: the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, Italy, the Kingdom of Belgium, the Kingdom of Denmark, the Kingdom of Norway, the Republic of Finland and the Republic of Ireland; GSI - Succursale de Paris (Paris branch) which is authorised by the French Autorite de controle prudentiel et de resolution ("ACPR") and regulated by the Autorite de controle prudentiel et de resolution and the Autorite des marches financiers ("AMF") disseminates research in France; GSI - Succursal en Espana (Madrid branch) authorized in Spain by the Comision Nacional del Mercado de Valores disseminates research in the Kingdom of Spain; GSI - Sweden Bankfall (Stockholm branch) is authorized by the SFSA as a "third country branch" in accordance with Chapter 4, Section 4 of the Swedish Securities and Market Act (Sw. lag (2007:528) on vardepappersmarknaden) disseminates research in the Kingdom of Sweden; Goldman Sachs Bank Europe SE ("GSBE") is a credit institution incorporated in Germany and, within the Single Supervisory Mechanism, subject to direct prudential supervision by the European Central Bank and in other respects supervised by German Federal Financial Supervisory Authority (Bundesanstalt fur Finanzdienstleistungsaufsicht, BaFin) and Deutsche Bundesbank and disseminates research in the Federal Republic of Germany and those jurisdictions within the European Economic Area where GSI is not authorised to disseminate research and additionally, GSBE, Copenhagen Branch filial of GSBE, Tyskland, supervised by the Danish Financial Authority disseminates research in the Kingdom of Denmark; GSBE - Succursal en Espana (Madrid branch) subject to a limited extent) to local supervision by the Bank of Spain disseminates research in the Kingdom of Spain; GSBE - Succursale Italia (Milan branch) to the relevant applicable extent, subject to local supervision by the Bank of Italy (Banca d'Italia) and the Italian Companies and Exchange Commission (Commissione Nazionale per le Societa e la Borsa "Consob") disseminates research in Italy; GSBE - Succursale de Paris (Paris branch), supervised by the AMF and by the ACPR disseminates research in France; and GSBE - Sweden Bankfall (Stockholm branch), to a limited extent, subject to local supervision by the Swedish Financial Supervisory Authority (Finansinspektionen) disseminates research in the Kingdom of Sweden.

This research is for our clients only. Other than disclosures relating to Goldman Sachs, this research is based on current public information that we consider reliable, but we do not represent it is accurate or complete, and it should not be relied on as such. The information, opinions, estimates and forecasts contained herein are as of the date hereof and are subject to change without prior notification. We seek to update our research as appropriate, but various regulations may prevent us from doing so. Other than certain industry reports published on a periodic basis, the large majority of reports are published at irregular intervals as appropriate in the analyst's judgment.

Goldman Sachs conducts a global full- service, integrated investment banking, investment management, and brokerage business. We have investment banking and other business relationships with a substantial percentage of the companies covered by Global Investment Research. Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC, the United States broker dealer, is a member of SIPC (https://www.sipc.org).

Our salespeople, traders, and other professionals may provide oral or written market commentary or trading strategies to our clients and principal trading desks that reflect opinions that are contrary to the opinions expressed in this research. Our asset management area, principal trading desks and investing businesses may make investment decisions that are inconsistent with the recommendations or views expressed in this research.

We and our affiliates, officers, directors, and employees will from time to time have long or short positions in, act as principal in, and buy or sell, the securities or derivatives, if any, referred to in this research, unless otherwise prohibited by regulation or Goldman Sachs policy.

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

Any third party referenced herein, including any salespeople, traders and other professionals or members of their household, may have positions in the products mentioned that are inconsistent with the views expressed by analysts named in this report.

This research is focused on investment themes across markets, industries and sectors. It does not attempt to distinguish between the prospects or performance of, or provide analysis of, individual companies within any industry or sector we describe.

Any trading recommendation in this research relating to an equity or credit security or securities within an industry or sector is reflective of the investment theme being discussed and is not a recommendation of any such security in isolation.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. It does not constitute a personal recommendation or take into account the particular investment objectives, financial situations, or needs of individual clients. Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character-risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fcm disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.

You are permitted to store, display, analyze, modify, reformat, and print the information made available to you via this service only for your own use. You may not resell or reverse engineer this information to calculate or develop any index for disclosure and/or marketing or create any other derivative works or commercial products), data or offerings) without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. You are not permitted to publish, transmit, or otherwise reproduce this information, in whole or in part, in any format to any third party without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. This foregoing restriction includes, without limitation, using, extracting, downloading or retrieving this information, in whole or in part, to train or finetune a machine learning or artificial intelligence system, or to provide or reproduce this information, in whole or in part, as a prompt or input to any such system.
